title: purity
comment: An absence of blemish or stain, especially sin. The state of being morally and spiritually pure, which is seen by Scripture as the result of being the people of God and also as an expected distinguishing mark of the church.

children.title: purity, nature of
children.comment: The OT recognises a close link between outer cleanliness and inner purity. In the NT, special emphasis is placed on inner purity resulting from spiritual renewal.

children.title: Physical cleansing from impurity by washing or refining
Ritual impurity must be avoided or cleansed

seealsos.comment: Fire is also a purifying agent.

children.title: Ritual purity is not required under the new covenant

primaryrefs.comment: What concerns God is moral impurity, associated with actions, not ritual impurity, associated with food, etc.

seealsos.comment: Paul took part in Jewish purification rites in accordance with his Jewish heritage
Peter temporarily relapsed into the habit of treating Gentiles as unclean

children.title: purity, moral and spiritual
children.comment: Moral and spiritual purity is demanded by God of his people. God calls his people to be holy, just as he is holy.

children.title: God's people are to live pure lives

seealsos.comment: Yeast is a symbol of sin

children.title: Purity is unobtainable by human effort
Because of the sinful human nature
Because of the tendency to idolatry
Because of an unwillingness to be cleansed
God promises to purify his people
Through pardon offered in his death
Through his presence in resisting temptation
Through hope built on his promises
